query.prompt:

Please translate literally into English and Esperanto.

query.result:
16 After the grievous rout, when 17 Charlemagne lost the holy army, 18 Orlando did not sound so terribly.
16 Post la dolorplena malvenko, kiam 17 Karolo la Granda perdis la sanktan armeon, 18 Orlando ne sonoris tiel terure.
Please note that "gesta" in line 17 is a difficult word to translate, as it can refer to a number of things, including a military expedition, a heroic deed, or a literary work. I have chosen to translate it as "army" in this context, but other translations are possible.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English and Esperanto.
19 Poco portäi in là volta la testa, 20 che me parve veder molte alte torri; 21 ond’ io: «Maestro, dì, che terra è questa?».
query.result:
19 I had turned my head there a little, 20 when it seemed to me that I saw many tall towers; 21 whereupon I said: "Master, tell me, what land is this?".
19 Malmulte mi portis tien la kapon, 20 ke ŝajnis al mi vidi multajn altajn turojn; 21 pro tio mi: "Majstro, diru, kia tero estas ĉi tiu?".
Please note that "porta" in line 19 is a conjugated form of the verb "portare", which means "to carry" or "to bring". In this context, it is used in the sense of "to turn" or "to direct".

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English and Esperanto.
28 Poi caramente mi prese per mano 29 e disse: «Pria che noi siam più avanti, 30 acciò che ’l fatto men ti paia strano,
31 sappi che non son torri, ma giganti, 32 e son nel pozzo intorno da la ripa 33 da l’umbilico in giuso tutti quanti».
query.result:
28 Then he took me gently by the hand 29 and said: "Before we go any further, 30 so that the fact may seem less strange to you,
31 know that they are not towers, but giants, 32 and they are in the well around the bank 33 from the navel down, all of them".
28 Poste karese li prenis min je per la mano 29 kaj diris: "Antaŭ ol ni estas pli antaŭe, 30 por ke la fakto malpli ŝajnu al vi stranga,
31 sciu ke ne estas turoj, sed gigantoj, 32 kaj estas en la puto ĉirkaŭe de la bordo 33 de la umbiliko malsupren ĉiuj".
Please note that "pria" in line 29 is an archaic form of the word "prima", which means "first" or "before".
Also, "umbilico" in line 33 means "navel".

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English and Esperanto.
34 Come quando la nebbia si dissipa, 35 lo sguardo a poco a poco raffigura 36 ciò che cela ’l vapor che l’aere stipa,
37 così forando l’aura grossa e scura, 38 più e più appressando ver’ la sponda, 39 fuggiemi errore e cresciemi paura;
40 però che, come su la cerchia tonda 41 Montereggion di torri si corona, 42 così la proda che ’l pozzo circonda
43 torreggiavan di mezza la persona 44 li orribili giganti, cui minaccia 45 Giove del cielo ancora quando tuona.
query.result:
34 As when the fog dissipates, 35 the gaze little by little makes out 36 that which the vapor that fills the air conceals,
37 so, piercing the thick and dark air, 38 drawing nearer and nearer to the bank, 39 error flees from me and fear grows in me;
40 because, as on the round circuit 41 Montereggion crowns itself with towers, 42 so the edge that surrounds the well
43 the horrible giants towered from the middle of their bodies, 44 whom Jove from heaven still threatens when he thunders.
34 Kiel kiam la nebulo disiĝas, 35 la rigardo iom post iom bildigas 36 tion kion kaŝas la vaporo kiu ŝtopas la aeron,
37 tiel trapikante la aeron dikan kaj malhelan, 38 pli kaj pli alproksimiĝante al la bordo, 39 eraro forkuras de mi kaj kreskas al mi timo;
40 ĉar, kiel sur la rondo 41 Montereggione kronas sin per turoj, 42 tiel la bordo kiu ĉirkaŭas la puton
43 turis de la mezo de la korpo 44 la terurajn gigantojn, kiujn minacas 45 Jupitero de la ĉielo ankoraŭ kiam li tondras.
Please note that "Montereggion" in line 41 is a castle in Tuscany, Italy, which is known for its circular walls and towers.
Also, "Giove" in line 45 is the Italian name for Jupiter, the Roman god of thunder and lightning.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English and Esperanto.
58 La faccia sua mi parea lunga e grossa 59 come la pina di San Pietro a Roma, 60 e a sua proporzione eran l’altre ossa;
61 sì che la ripa, ch’era perizoma 62 dal mezzo in giù, ne mostrava ben tanto 63 di sovra, che di giugnere a la chioma
64 tre Frison s’averien dato mal vanto; 65 però ch’i’ ne vedea trenta gran palmi 66 dal loco in giù dov’ omo affibbia ’l manto.
query.result:
58 His face seemed to me as long and wide 59 as the pine of Saint Peter's in Rome, 60 and his other bones were in proportion to it;
61 so that the bank, which was a loincloth 62 from the middle down, showed us clearly so much 63 of him above, that to reach his hair
64 three Frisians would have boasted in vain; 65 because I saw thirty great spans of him 66 from the place down where a man buckles his cloak.
58 Lia vizaĝo ŝajnis al mi longa kaj dika 59 kiel la pino de Sankta Petro en Romo, 60 kaj al lia proporcio estis la aliaj ostoj;
61 tiel ke la bordo, kiu estis subvesto 62 de la mezo malsupren, montris al ni bone tiom 63 de supre, ke por atingi la hararon
64 tri Frisoj estus sin vante malbone; 65 ĉar mi vidis tridek grandajn palmojn de li 66 de la loko malsupren kie homo alkroĉas la mantelon.
Please note that "pina" in line 59 can also mean "pineapple", but in this context it is used in the sense of "pine cone".
Also, "Frisoni" in line 64 are a people from the Netherlands and northwestern Germany who are known for their tall stature.
Finally, "palmo" in line 66 is a unit of measurement equal to about 8 inches or 20 centimeters.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English and Esperanto.
115 «O tu che ne la fortunata valle 116 che fece Scipïon di gloria reda, 117 quand’ Anibàl co’ suoi diede le spalle,
118 recasti già mille leon per preda, 119 e che, se fossi stato a l’alta guerra 120 de’ tuoi fratelli, ancor par che si creda
121 ch’avrebber vinto i figli de la terra: 122 mettine giù, e non ten vegna schifo, 123 dove Cocito la freddura serra.
query.result:
115 "O you who in the fortunate valley 116 that made Scipio heir to glory, 117 when Hannibal and his men turned their backs,
118 once brought back a thousand lions as prey, 119 and who, if you had been at the great war 120 of your brothers, it still seems to be believed
121 that the sons of the earth would have won: 122 put us down, and let it not disgust you, 123 where Cocytus encloses the cold.
115 "Ho vi kiu en la feliĉa valo 116 kiu faris Scipionon heredanto de gloro, 117 kiam Hanibalo kun siaj viroj turnis la dorson,
118 iam revenigis mil leonojn kiel predon, 119 kaj kiu, se vi estus ĉe la alta milito 120 de viaj fratoj, ankoraŭ ŝajnas ke oni kredas
121 ke venkus la filoj de la tero: 122 metu nin malsupren, kaj ne venu al vi abomeno, 123 kie Cocito enfermas la malvarmon.
Please note that "fortunata valle" in line 115 refers to the valley of Zama in North Africa, where Scipio Africanus defeated Hannibal in the Second Punic War.
Also, "Scipïon" in line 116 is the Italian form of the name Scipio.
Finally, "Cocito" in line 123 is one of the rivers of the underworld in Greek and Roman mythology.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English and Esperanto.
124 Non ci fare ire a Tizio né a Tifo: 125 questi può dar di quel che qui si brama; 126 però ti china e non torcer lo grifo.

query.prompt:

130 Così disse ’l maestro; e quelli in fretta 131 le man distese, e prese ’l duca mio, 132 ond’ Ercule sentì già grande stretta.
query.result:
130 Thus spoke the master; and he in haste 131 stretched out his hands, and seized my leader, 132 so that Hercules once felt a great squeeze.
130 Tiel diris la majstro; kaj tiu haste 131 etendis la manojn, kaj prenis mian dukon, 132 pro kio Herkulo iam sentis grandan premon.
Please note that "fretta" in line 131 can also mean "haste" or "hurry", but in this context it is used in the sense of "eagerness" or "enthusiasm".
Also, "Ercule" in line 132 is the Italian form of the name Hercules.
Finally, "stretta" in line 132 can also mean "narrowing" or "contraction", but in this context it is used in the sense of "squeeze" or "grip".

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English and Esperanto.
133 Virgilio, quando prender si sentio, 134 disse a me: «Fatti qua, sì ch’io ti prenda»; 135 poi fece sì ch’un fascio era elli e io.
query.result:
133 Virgil, when he felt himself being seized, 134 said to me: "Come here, so that I may take you"; 135 then he made it so that he and I were one bundle.
133 Virgilio, kiam li sentis sin esti prenita, 134 diris al mi: "Venu ĉi tien, por ke mi vin prenu"; 135 poste li faris tiel ke fasko estis li kaj mi.
Please note that "prendere" in line 133 can also mean "to take" or "to seize", but in this context it is used in the sense of "to capture" or "to catch".
Also, "fascio" in line 135 can also mean "bundle" or "sheaf", but in this context it is used in the sense of "group" or "mass".

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English and Esperanto.
136 Qual pare a riguardar la Carisenda 137 sotto ’l chinato, quando un nuvol vada 138 sovr’ essa sì, ched ella incontro penda:
139 tal parve Antëo a me che stava a bada 140 di vederlo chinare, e fu tal ora 141 ch’i’ avrei voluto ir per altra strada.
query.result:
136 As the Garisenda seems to look 137 from beneath its overhang, when a cloud passes 138 over it so that it leans against it:
139 such seemed Antaeus to me, who was waiting 140 to see him bend down, and there was a time 141 when I would have liked to go by another way.
136 Kiel ŝajnas rigardi la Carisenda 137 sub la klinita, kiam nubo iras 138 super ĝin tiel, ke ĝi kontraŭe klinas:
139 tia ŝajnis Anteo al mi kiu atendis 140 vidi lin kliniĝi, kaj estis tia horo 141 ke mi estus volinta iri per alia vojo.
Please note that "Carisenda" in line 136 is a leaning tower in Bologna, Italy.
Also, "chinato" in line 137 can also mean "bent" or "curved", but in this context it is used in the sense of "overhang" or "projection".
Finally, "bada" in line 140 can also mean "delay" or "hesitation", but in this context it is used in the sense of "waiting" or "expectation".

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English and Esperanto.
142 Ma lievemente al fondo che divora 143 Lucifero con Giuda, ci sposò; 144 né, sì chinato, lì fece dimora,
145 e come albero in nave si levò.
query.result:
142 But he gently set us down at the bottom that devours 143 Lucifer with Judas; 144 nor, so bent down, did he stay there,
145 but like a mast in a ship he rose up.
142 Sed milde al la fundo kiu forkonsumas 143 Lucifero kun Judaso, li edzinigis nin; 144 nek, tiel klinita, tie li restis,
145 kaj kiel arbo en ŝipo li leviĝis.
Please note that "sposare" in line 143 can also mean "to marry" or "to unite in marriage", but in this context it is used in the sense of "to set down" or "to place".
Also, "dimora" in line 144 can also mean "dwelling" or "abode", but in this context it is used in the sense of "stay" or "sojourn".
Finally, "albero" in line 145 can also mean "tree" or "plant", but in this context it is used in the sense of "mast" or "pole".
